title: andrebbe tenuto meglio
text: Mi aveva incuriosito questo sito perch√© √® l‚Äôunico sito UNESCO culturale del paese. Purtroppo non c'√® molto da vedere poich√© parte degli edifici non √® visitabile, i pochi reperti sono in vetrine polverose e non si possono fare foto tranne che nel cortile dove sono in vendita articoli per turisti. Anche i tradizionali tetti di paglia sono stati sostituiti con lamiere arrugginite aumentando un'impressione di degrado. Interessanti le spiegazioni ma sarebbe da tenere meglio.

title: Historical value, unfortunately not well preserved.
text:
A visit to the palace(s) is something you must do. But it is really a pity it is not better maintained. It has great historic and cultural value.
We had a great English speaking guide, who also guided us around further in the city of Abomey.
Guide : Hyacinthe  + 229 95 54 46 33
Aside from that very few things foreseen for tourists (icl. Toilet). But it seems some investments to come with the French cooperation.

The Palace is still being used by the King, so when the king is there you take off your shoes (hot sand!)  And can be a bit crowded because of ceremonies.
Photos not allowed, but can work around that üôÉ.

title: Interesting and peaceful place to visit
text:
We really enjoyed our visit but agree with others that there isn‚Äôt much information given by the palace itself, so for the best experience you should go with a guide. With a guide we found the visit and the palace really interesting and enjoyed learning about the history of Abomey. 
(We visited with English-speaking guide, Mark, who is one of a group of guides from across the country who were trained up by the government. Mark was excellent and showed us all the best sites of Abomey. We sadly did not note down his surname but your hotel should be able to help you find him, as ours did).

title: Une visite incontournable √† Abomey
text: Il n'y a pas grand chose √† voir malheureusement car la plupart des b√¢timents ne sont pas accessibles. On prend conscience de la taille du site, l'histoire est bien racont√©e par les guides, mais il est interdit de photographier ( alors que de nos jours ce sont les r√©seaux sociaux qui suscitent l'envie ). Les quelques reliques sont enferm√©es dans des pr√©sentoirs poussi√©reux dans des b√¢timents sans √©clairage. Vraiment dommage car le B√©nin tient l√† un potentiel touristique exceptionnel qu'il ne sait malheureusement pas exploiter. Cela reste tout de m√™me une visite incontournable √† Abomey.

title: Interesting regional history
text:
The tour has to be done without shoes and it's a big compound, We were also told that photos weren't allowed during the tour. Organizing a guide is essential because there is a lot of history and there aren't any plaques through the palace describing the artifacts or functions. It is still a functioning palace and while we were there the acting King was holding court in the main courtyard and there were ceremonies which was interesting to experience. 

It was explained to us that the Kingdom of Abomey was the only kingdom in West Africa with an female security force which was established when one of the queens was ruling the kingdom for some years. Our guide explained this to us but the tour would have been improved if there was a plaque that described the circumstances and historical context. 

There were several interesting displays especially the original thrown which was very tall and was resting on the skulls of defeated kings.

title: Abomey m√©rite mieux que des palais d√©grad√©s !
text:
Abomey a √©t√© depuis le premier roi Gangnihesdou ( 1600-1621) jusqu'au dernier Behanzin ( 1889-1894)  un puissant royaume appel√© plus tard  royaume du Dahomey ( nom francis√©). Ces rois de droit divin et au pouvoir absolu , avaient droit de vie et de mort sur leurs sujets.  Ils pratiquaient la d√©capitation , sans h√©siter.  Ils ont , pendant la p√©riode de l'esclavage, vendu nombre de leurs vaincus et de leurs sujets aux n√©griers europ√©ens . Le march√© de Ouidah a √©t√© florissant pendant des si√®cles.

Le syst√®me royal est enti√®rement r√©gl√© par le roi qui dispose d'un nombre important de concubines qui sont suppervisees par la reine m√®re.  Les derniers rois utilisaient  des amazones, femmes entra√Æn√©es √† la guerre , qui sont rest√©es fid√®les jusqu'√† dernier moment pendant la conqu√™te fran√ßaise, qui a d√©pos√© le roi Behanzin en 1894 . Avec sa redoutable arm√©e,  le royaume √† vassalise les autres royaumes de l'actuel B√©nin √† l'exception de celui de Hogbonou ( Porto Novo ) o√π le roi  Joffa avait d√©j√† conclu un accord commercial avec la France en 1882.
Le roi Behanzin , bien qu'ayant r√®gne que 5 ans , est tr√®s populaire , car  il est le symbole de la r√©sistance contre l'envahisseur fran√ßais   qui a eut du mal √† le vaincre, malgr√© une sup√©riorit√© num√©rique et technologique. 

La visite de ce mus√©e est d√©cevante  , par la v√©tust√© des lieux , la m√©diocrit√© en valeur des quelques objets et par l'interdiction de prendre des photos , que je consid√®re comme contre productive pour la promotion du site .Seules les explications  du guide sont d√©taill√©es et int√©ressantes. Le seul endroit o√π les photos sont autoris√©es est la premi√®re cour o√π les marchands du temple pr√©sentent leurs objets pour touristes. A noter que ce qui donne une impression de d√©gradation sont les t√¥les rouill√©es qui ont remplac√© les toits traditionnels en paille . De m√™me, les vitrines qui pr√©sentent des objets sont tellement sales qu 'on a du mal √† les distinguer !

L'entr√©e est payante 1000 francs pour les beninois et 3000 francs pour les autres .

title: Tr√®s bel h√©ritage du royaume du Dahomey
text: Vaste domaine royal o√π l'on peut d√©couvrir le pass√© culturel tr√®s riche de cette partie du B√©nin. Tr√®s bon guide en prime

title: Une visite incontournable et int√©ressante
text: Je n'√©tais plus all√© la-bas depuis des ann√©es. Malheureusement l'endroit est d√©cr√©pie faute d'argent pour l'entretenir. C'est d√©sormais gratuit pour tous. Un excellent guide connaissant bien son histoire nous √† fait visiter les lieux pendant 1H30. c'√©tait bien expliqu√©. Pas grand chose √† voir dans les b√¢timents et les quelques objets expos√©s sont poussi√©reux et les vitrines suffisamment sales pour emp√™cher de lire les explications. Malgr√© cela, √ßa reste int√©ressant, il faut le faire. Les artisans locaux, √† la sortie, sont sympas et les articles pas trop chers ( mais bien sur, toujours n√©gocier le prix ). N'oublier pas de prendre une bouteille d'eau avec vous.

title: See it - but with a guide
text:
Its a little difficult for an European to be impressed by these few clay-based, single story bulidings. They are ancient by the standards in Benin, as they have been constructed around 1830-ish. Unfortunately they did not refurbish ANY of the furniture, maps & graphics hanging on the walls. Most of them are impossible to read. 

They have a much venerated grave of the king Ghezo, which they believe is still with us, as the hut was supposed to be his room. There used to be furniture, but they threw it out, and nobody cared enough to even put a random bed  and some chairs there to pretend that they are the originals. 

There are a few artifacts in the museum - some of them very interesting but in high state of disrepair. By that I mean that they are literally falling apart. The famous  throne with 4 skulls is in a glass cabinet so dirty that you can barely see the shape of that throne.

But dont be discouraged by all this. Get a guide to tell you the stories behind all that and you will really enjoy your time.

title: A must for the history!
text: A rather interesting but harsh history of the royals. I'd definitely recommend as a lot of history here. Guide was excellent. The grounds are v big. Definitely worth a visit..

title: le roi B√©hanzin
text:
e #Roi_Gb√®hanzin et une partie de sa famille ont √©t√© d√©port√©s vers la Martinique. Apr√®s plusieurs ann√©es d'une farouche guerre anticolonialiste, #Gb√®hanzin se rendra au Colonel Dodds pour √©pargner son peuple mais aussi pour essayer d'aller trouver des explications √† cette invasion aupr√®s du pr√©sident fran√ßais Carnot. 

Le roi du Danxom√® se faisait alors accompagner de son fils Wanignilo, de son cousin Adand√©djan, 3 de ses filles, 4 reines et du couple Fanou, son traducteur. 

Gb√®hanzin ne rencontrera jamais aucun pr√©sident fran√ßais, il mourra 12 ans plus tard √† Blida (Alg√©rie) de col√®re et de maladie.

La suite, c'est 125 ans de pillage, d'humiliation, de d√©shumanisation, qui laisseront place √† la corruption, l'irresponsabilit√© et √† l'incurie de notre √©lite.

title: le roi b√©hanzin
text:
B√©hanzin n√© en 1845 et mort en 1906, est traditionnellement le onzi√®me roi d‚ÄôAbomey. Fils de Da-Da Gl√®l√® Kini-Kini, B√©hanzin est d‚Äôabord connu sous le nom d‚ÄôAhokponu puis de prince Kondo √† partir de 1875.

B√©hanzin est Roi du Dahomey du 6 janvier 1890 au 15 janvier 1894, date de sa reddition. Il d√©c√®de √† Blida (Alger) le 10 d√©cembre 1906. √ätre sacr√©, il porte plusieurs titres : Dada (p√®re de toute la communaut√©), Dokounnon (d√©tenteur et dispensateur de biens), S√®m√®do (ma√Ætre du monde), A√Ønon (ma√Ætre de la terre), J√®hossou (ma√Ætre des perles), etc.

Ses insignes de pouvoir sont le katakl√® (tabouret tripode), les afokpa (sandales), le avotita (pagne tiss√© et d√©cor√© de motifs appliqu√©s), le aw√® (parasol), le makpo (spetre), le so (fusil) et lehwi (sabre). Il a √©t√© mari√© √† douze femmes et a eu probablement plus de cinquante enfants.

title: Belle h√©ritage du pass√©.
text: Ce n'est pas le Louvre bien entendu mais une belle part de l'histoire des rois d'Abomey vous sera racont√© par des guides comp√©tents. NB, une r√©novation du site est pr√©vue, une belle invitation au tourisme au B√©nin.

title: Interesting place
text: The place itself does not really look like a palace, but with a good guide you do get the story and the right impression. We liked especially the strange clay figurines on the walls and the stories behind them, they are quite unique. Do ask about their active involvement in the slave trade - it made them insanely rich and powerful.

title: Museum has been closed
text: Just visited the foundation today. The museum has been closed since December 2019 and is not planning to be opened anytime soon in Cotonou. The staff here says that theres a museum in Ouida that‚Äôs currently open. What‚Äôs left of the museum here is just a shop of books and textiles. It also acts as a cafe, although the cafe staff is not very friendly. When I asked if there‚Äôs a book about the museum history (since the museum is closed and I came all the way), they pointed me to a book. However, to sit down and read it, they demanded me to buy something to drink at the cafe. Or I could not use the chairs and had to stand. There was no other customer and all seats were empty. In the end, I had to stand there glancing through the book. This experience left a rather bad taste in the mouth and in my few contradictory to what the foundation is about - advocating the art of Africa. For future visitors, may best visit the museum in Ouida.

text:

Tout d'abord, la bonne adresse ... Cette fondation n'est plus dans le quartier Cadj√©houn (l'adresse donn√©e dans le petit fut√© est obsol√®te)(comme la moiti√© du guide B√©nin 2018 d'ailleurs !!!).

title: One of a kind phenomenal
text: This museum and educational foundation is not to be missed in any trip to Benin. Even if you don‚Äôt know anything about contemporary African Art‚Äî or, like me, think maybe you secretly don‚Äôt even like contemporary art very much, because sometimes it‚Äôs so hard to grasp‚Äî I entreat you to visit this place! The exhibition guides are so well trained and explain the art in a plain-spoken, very clear and interactive way that is both enlightening and enjoyable. It‚Äôs a wonderful place for kids, families, art experts and newcomers to contemporary art alike. I‚Äôve visited art museums around the world and have never seen one quite like this. A super special place.

title: Slave route ... port of no return
text: The monument is basic, but its history lessons are very confronting. So many slaves left Africa here. You can have a walk in the area, drink something at the beach "club" and visit nearby museums. Recommend to visit by (taxi)motor and by foot...

title: World Heritage Site
text: Right there on the beach - Ouidah Plage - stands the memorial built by UNESCO to commemorate the horrors of the slave trade which saw several thousands of Africans sold as slaves and shipped off across the Atlantic Ocean. La Porte du Non-retour (Door of No Return marks the final leg of the slave route where they bid farewell to Africa forever.

title: Un monument int√©ressant √† visiter
text: A voir, en passant √† Ouidah. Un monument symbolique, rappelant la traite des esclaves, le d√©part par mer vers une destination inconnue. L'horreur de l'exploitation et de l'esclavage.

title: Slave route - a history lesson on human rights
text:
Our visit to Ouidah centred around the slave route.

We followed the route from the slave market in the middle of town along the 4 km trek to the sea. Slaves were forced to walk,  chained together (neck to neck), in the blistering heat or pounding rain to be boarded onto ships awaiting departure for the Americas. 

We also visited the museum which is housed in the old Portuguese fort in Ouidah. At the museum we learned that the slave trade was not one-sided. The Dahomey kings traded slaves for gifts and weapons from the Europeans. 

Visiting the slave route is a sombre experience similar to visiting a holocaust camp. We all know what happened but seeing the site first-hand makes you really think what it must have been like for the victims. 

 At the place where the slave route meets the sea is the the Door of No Return. The monument was erected in 1994 in memory of the 15,000,000 slaves that boarded those ships. It's estimated that for every slave that boarded a ship another died en route to the coast. 

This is a must-see if you're travelling in Benin.

title: Sehr beeindruckend, wundersch√∂ner Strand
text: Durch dieser Bogen mussten damals die Sklaven' die vorher 4 km weiter in Ouidah in der Festung zusammengepfercht wurden, gehen. Der Weg finde von der Festung quasi gerade aus bis zum Meer, wo bereits die Zweimaster warteten auf die √úberfahrt nach Amerika. Leider konnten viele ersch√∂pfte Sklaven diese Boote nicht mehr erreichen, oder versuchten von den Beibooten zu springen und ertranken qualvoll. Alles war Ihnen lieber, als in dieser unbekannte Zukunft als Sklave abgef√ºhrt zu werden. Es ist sehr beeindruckend, diesen Weg als freier Mensch zu gehen, und dieser Manmal ist eine sch√∂ne Hommage an den armen Seelen

title: Route des esclaves
text:
Pour faire la route, il faut d abord passer a l office du tourisme pour payer. Un enfant du pays (guide) voys accompagne pendant 1h jusqu a la porte de non retour. Qui ne represent aucun interet en elle-meme, mais les histoires racontees par le guide sont tres interessantes.
Ca vaut le coup!

title: great trip
text: we rented bikes and a guide for this day and it was nica and intersting experience. nice adventure recomanded for history lovers

title: Cool thing to do in Benin
text: Filled with historical background, the Porte du non retour (Gate of no return) is a reminder of the great tragedy that was the slave trade. On a lighter note, the beach on which it stands is beautiful, and I would recommend buying some fresh coconuts from the street vendors !

title: Perhaps the Main Attraction of Benin
text:
The monument itself is underwhelming but still interesting. 

It is basically a gate with some sculptures on the beach, facing the sea...

The visit won't take long (maybe 10-20 minutes if you really focus on the details), but there are guides for hire, who can give you some more information and offer to show you other sites related to the slave trade (the trees, the ditch...)... I hired a guide only for the Porte du Non Retour. To be honest, I did not find it very interesting and most information is information you'll find online...

The guide costs 2000CFA for the Gate tour (and I believe 5000CFA if you want them to take you to the other sites), so might as well get one to inject some money in the local economy...

Not far from this monument (200 meters) is the Porte du Retour, which is a but unrelated, and focuses on the arrival of Christian missionaries.

title: Visite √©mouvante
text: La porte de Ouidah ou du non retour √† '√©poque de l'esclavage organis√©.  A faire avec un guide.  Au passage, visiter le centre artisanal

title: Tor zur Erinnerung an die Sklavereigeschichte
text: Das Tor ist ein modern designtes Bauwerk, aber die Geschichte dahinter ist tragisch. Man sollte sich viel √ºber die Sklavereigeschichte erz√§hlen lassen, um das Ausma√ü der Inhumanit√§t zu verstehen.

title: Super guide
text: On venait voir la porte du non retour lorsqu'on est tomb√© sur Geoffroy. Guide depuis 9 ans, tr√®s bon guide. Il nous a fait une visite bien plus importante que tout les autres guides qui passaient par l√† avec leurs clients et on l'a gard√© pour le festival Vodoun. On en a eu plein les yeux et on a appris √©norm√©ment de choses.

title: La porte de non retour d'o√π vous reviendrez changer !
text:
La porte de non-retour est un emplacement symbolique et √† absolument voir lorsque nous somme de passage sur Ouidah. 

Cet endroit est charg√© d'√©motions et ne nous pouvons qu'√™tre d√©sempar√© face √† cette histoire dont nous sommes tous concern√©s.

title: A monument that really makes you think about History of slavery
text: This monument is a symbol as well as a great well maintained architectural conception. It has a significant importance for the cultural history of Benin. There is also a small market besides that sells souvenirs.

text: guided tours available, interesting and historically significant location. check out the surroundings

title: History of slavery
text: Very moving place showing the "door of no return" which Slaves passed through to board ships for abroad. Amazing detail on the reliefs.

title: Om stil van te zijn
text: Als je van Ouidah richting la porte du non retour loopt, denk dan eens aan de slaven die richting de west gingen en wisten dat ze nooit meer terug kwamen. In Ouidah zijn ze van hun identiteit beroofd en aangekomen bij de plek waar de poort staat lagen de schepen klaar. Een hele indrukwekkende plek, maar trek zeker ook even de tijd uit om het geheel te ervaren!

title: Overwhelmed with the details
text: If you looking for real facts about slavery, this is the place. The story begins from the cha-cha place, all the way to where the rituals are performed till the last slave got on board the ship. It was sober reflection moment for me. It could be quite challenging if you do not understand French or any of the local languages fon or yoruba. A guide could charge as much as 5000cfa and it's nice to buy them lunch as well. Be careful because someone might take advantage of you in that town especially money related.

title: Sobering place to visit
text: Beautiful Memorial to all those who left right from this beach to the New World during the slave era. Rather unfortunately it is not being kept as it should!

title: Frightning
text: One has always to remember the past and learn for the future. ...the place could be cleaner to honor the human beings having been dragged through this so peaceful place.

title: Nicht w√§hrend der Regenzeit...
text:
Wir waren Ende September 2013 im Park. W√§hrend und nach der Regenzeit kann ich es niemandem empfehlen. Die Vegetation ist 3m hoch und man sieht keinen Meter weit (kein Witz!). Die Zufahrtsstrasse in den Park ist zudem so stark zerst√∂rt nach der Regenzeit, dass wir zweimal mit dem Fahrzeut steckengeblieben sind. Zudem wurden wir √ºbers Ohr gehauen und mussten den vollen Preis beim Park bezahlen... Wir haben in einem ganzen Tag nur 6 Antilopen und eine kleine Affengruppe gesehen, mehr nicht.
Deshalb unbedingt bis Dezember / Januar warten; die Parkw√§chter brennen das Gras dann kontrolliert ab und man hat eine Chance, die Tiere zu sehen.

title: Lions at their very best!
text: I have been on several safaris in Africa (S. Africa, Uganda) and never have I been able to get as close to lions as at Parc Pendjari.  For over an hour we watched them mate, eat a buffalo they had killed and then sit nuzzling each other, nose to nose.  It was amazing!  In all, there were eight lions circling our wagon but completely unfazed by us and as long as we kept quiet very calm.  I thoroughly recommend Pendjari, which is quiet, tranquil and not at all touristy.  Other animals in abundance too - hippos, baboons, antelope, warthogs, elephants - plus absolutely gorgeous birds

title: seriously cool place
text:
This is our first safari experience, hence we might be overexcited about Pendjari, but I think it is really worth a visit. Even during Christmas holidays there were not too many tourists, so it is very tranquil and quiet with lots of opportunities to see the wildlife. we managed to spot lions, elephants, crocodiles, monkeys, countless "gazelles" and a lot of other stuff.

As other reviewers said it is very handy to stay at the Pendjari hotel because then you can get up rather early and start your animal hunting, otherwise it will take you at least two hours to get there, and the best time to see the animals is early mornings.

title: the best genuine national park experience
text:
We stayed in the park for 3 nights at the Pendjari Lodge. After getting the park experience, I can only say that 1 week is minimum time that you should spend in Pendjari park. It's a great place to take your time off, relax and get to know the nature as well as the wide spectrum of wildlife.

Super recommended.

title: Beautiful Park
text: We spent 2 days and nights in the Pendjari hotel and park in February 2013. In only 2 days, we saw many elephants, buffalos, baboons, warthogs, antelopes, lots of birds, hippo's and crocodiles in this beautiful park. Our guide even managed to find us some lions, which are not so abundantly present. We saw a couple drive in the park themselves, however, we cannot recommend this. The guides have trained eyes for the various species and spot animals much earlier than we "untrained" people can. Most of the beauty (and explanation) is missed without an "A" qualified guide, such as our Kounta N'TCHA (kounta-guide-pendjari.blogspot.com), since driving itself already consumes most of the attention. We (2 couples) can wholeheartedly recommend the park for a photo-safari. It is less commercial and sophisticated than the known parks in the "East" and "South" of Africa and the number of tourists is low, which makes the whole experience a lot more "private". Enjoy your stay there!

title: Parque Magnifico
text: No he estado en ningun otro parque nacional de Africa, este ha sido el unico y es la 2¬™ vez que voy, merece la pena, no esta nada masificado, sin cientos de turistas, que te quiten el sitio para hacer fotos, ni corriendo porque otros todoterrenos te adelanten, las intalaciones del hotel del parque son dignas sin ser lujosas, pero es que el parque y su fauna es magnifico.

title: Parc nature
text:
Le parc de la Pendjari est vraiment nature ; wild life. Le campement est un tr√®s bon deal pour s√©journer deux nuits.
Je d√©conseille vivement d'engager Mathieu Sanhouekoua comme chauffeur-guide : ce monsieur est fonci√®rement malhonn√™te pour un circuit au B√©nin ; il "raconte des salades" pour que vous choisissiez les h√¥tels o√π il touche grosse commission etc etc.

title: Rugged Safari
text:
We've been to Pendjari many times, and we continue to go back.  It's certainly more rugged and less developed than the parks we visited in East Africa, but it preserved the feeling of being in the wild, and in the animals' territory better than said parks as well.  The hotel within the park is rather bare, but fine, and the food they serve is decent as well.  We have also camped in the park, and that was a lot of fun but a bit scary!

We always see plenty of antelopes, Cape buffalo, warthogs, crocs, hippos, baboons, monkeys, elephants, and many types of birds.  We see lions on about half of our trips.  We have a wonderful guide who's parents grew up in the area, and was trained as a safari guide as part of the park program to employ local people.  He was very knowledgable and thoughtful of our needs.

title: experience our animals - safe our animals
text:
the parc is very well organised, no mass tourism, well equiped and trained guides who are also drivers and will drive you safely through the parc.
It is worthwile to stay some nights in the Pendjari hotel; outside the parc  instead the TataSomba Hotel in Natitingou is absolutely recommendable with its quiet atmosphere and its professional and kind maitre d'hotel (Mr. Koffi).

text:
Avec quelques amis, nous avons quitt√© le tumulte de Cotonou le temps d'une journ√©e pour venir nous ressourcer. Je conseille √† tout voyageur de passage √† Cotonou de visiter cet endroit !

title: Our favorite day trip
text: It is really our favorite place for a day trip. Wonderful short boat trip trough the mangrove. Then Just sitting on the dock, having a glass and relaxing, while the kids are either on the playground or in the water. The food is great as well. Then just a bit of exercise on the canoes or kayak there. Ideal way to spend quality time with the kids.

title: Best place outside Cotonou
text: Bab's Dock is located outside Cotonou. Take the Route de Peche around 20 mins and don't miss the sign to go right just before Helvetica. Park your car and take the small boat that will ferry you through the mangrove and across the lake to Bab's Dock. Excellent start! This is a place to chill, listen music and have a drink. Food is not so much recommended. Quality is not that good and it is overprized. Still highly recommended!

title: un havre de paix
text:
Loin du tumulte et de la pollution de Cotonou, il fait bon de passer la journ√©e dans ce havre de paix.
C'est un couple de belges qui sont √† l‚Äôorigine de cette id√©e et tout est mis en ≈ìuvre pour que vous puissiez vous ressourcer.
Le cadre est vraiment tr√®s sympa, et on y acc√®de en pirogue, apr√®s avoir suivi un cours d'eau traversant la mangrove.

Puis on arrive au ponton qui dessert cette ile ( ou plut√¥t presqu'ile... Mais tout est fait pour que vous vous sentiez sur une ile.)
Baignade, farniente,bar, restaurant, on profite de tout et on se d√©tend vraiment.

Pour vous y rendre, prenez la route des p√™ches et vous verrez un panneau sur votre droite. suivez le jusqu'√† l'embarcad√®re.

title: Stunning, ;long and huge beach
text: The beach is one of the most stunning and long and huge beaches in the world. Unfortunately is not maintained and especially in Fidjrosse area is quite dirty, filled with plastic bags, and with humans corporal remains (there are a lot of huts in that area on the beach and people go to pee and poo on the shores...). The beach starts to be better and less dirty after 3/4 KM from Fidjrosse where there are less people living in the huts on the beach, or there are only the fishermen that keep the beach proper and livable. Their activity is a must to see when you are there, although they don't like you to take picture of them. I really love the beach and the local Government should take care more of this superb nature gift they have.

title: Vagues √† l'√¢me...

title: Le refuge des habitants de Cotonou
text:
Une longue plage qui s'√©tale de l‚Äôa√©roport jusqu'√† Ouida, il n'y a pas de route goudronn√©e juste la piste. la mer est un peu dangereuse m√™me si vous √™tes ou pas un grand nageur. Plein de petit restaurant, mais g√©n√©ralement quand y allait, je loue des petite paillote pour la journ√©e (10‚Ç¨ toute la journ√©e 15‚Ç¨ avec les chaises).  Attention, il faut quitter avant de faire nuit.

text: Facile d'acc√®s en zem, la plage de Fidjeross√© est un bel endroit pour passer un bon moment, observer la population locale, boire une bi√®re ou manger une noix de coco sous une des paillottes de la palge

title: Sunday afternoon people watching

title: Quite an experience
text: I visited here since it was the sacred temple of the Voodoo religion. So read up on it first to know the background helps to appreciate it better.  Its a tiny temple with a huge 700 year old sacred tree that is also worshiped.  People come there to ask for boons and if granted they pay a second visit to give whatever they promised.  You can see the bones of chickens and goats which had been sacrificed there.  The highlight is the sacred pythons which are either sleeping, some of them crawling about inside the temple.  They allow you to carry the python, or the guide places it around your neck.The doors of the temple are open once a month to allow them to go out inside the town or wherever, feed and many return after a day or two.

text:
Visitar o Porte du non retour, em Ouidah, √© conhecer um pouco da nossa hist√≥ria.

Mas existe esse significado hist√≥rico, essa simbologia, que n√£o deixa de ter seu apelo, especialmente para os filhos da "diaspora negra" e para os africanos que ficaram.

title: Au bord de la fa√ßade atlantique
text:
La porte du non retour cl√¥t un parcours mais en ouvre un autre. 

Ici s‚Äôarr√™te un chemin. Celui qui part des contr√©es africaines aux bateaux n√©griers √† destination de l‚ÄôEurope et de l‚ÄôAm√©rique.

Ici commence un autre parcours, l‚Äôenfer des les calles n√©gri√®res, le d√©but d‚Äôune autre vie de servitude.

title: De passage au B√©nin, endroit √† voir!
text:
Lieu important de l'histoire du B√©nin, parcours √† faire √† pied et pourquoi pas accompagn√© d'un guide.

√âmotions garanties.

title: Elegantly sobering reminder
text: Located on the beach near Ouidah, the elegant arch is a poignant reminder of the horror of being loaded on a ship as property to sell in the new world, never to see your family and home again.

title: An incredible experience
text: It is a memorial to all the slaves taken from Benin and sold in the American continent (Brazil and the caribean, mostly). The local guides provide you with the historical background and make your tour a much better experience. Take the time to listen to them and reward them with a little tip (about 1.500 to 2.000 XOF is reasonable). They deserve it.

title: Poignant reminder of slavery in West Africa
text:
This particular sight serves as a poignant reminder of the thousands of West Africans who walked across this beach to a life of slavery (or death en route).  However, rather than heading straight here, I suggest that you find a guide in the city (there are plenty near the museums or Temple of Pythons) and tour the entire slave route.  It only takes about 40 minutes, but it will give you a greater sense of the inhumanity of Man.

The gate itself is a stunning memorial with four fabulous iron sculptures at each corner.  My heart sank as I walked through, knowing that I could return, whereas slaves would only ever return in spirit, never in body.

This is must-see!

title: Coup de coeur,
text: Encore un passage oblig√© si vous passez par Ouidah. Ce site est un lieu important de l'histoire du B√©nin. On ne peut s‚Äôemp√™cher de se mettre √† la place de ces gens qui ont √©t√© arrach√© √† leur terre natale pour √™tre plac√© sous le joug de l'esclavage des occidentaux. La souffrance pass√©e s'y ressent encore.

title: History at its peak
text: It was great to know the history of the slaves During that time. We walked the same road they did upto the port. It was so heartbreaking. I cried.

title: √âmouvant
text: C'est une visite tr√®s √©mouvante surtout apr√®s le parcours de la route des esclaves en passant par le village o√π se trouve la case de zomai ainsi que le cimeti√®re des esclaves. Triste d'imaginer ces milliers d'√™tres humains arrach√©s √† leur terre et d√©port√©s en pays inconnu √† l'√©poque.  Le site est tr√®s int√©ressant. A voir

text: I wrote a similar review explaining about the museum. This is the last part of the slaves-rue. who  left  from this port  over  200 years  and  for  most it was their last step in Africa .   Its  one tribe  enslaving  another  and  selling to the Dutch, Brazillains, English,  etc

title: Emocionante
text:
Por ser brasileiro e por ser descendente de africanos fiz toda a rota com um n√≥ na garganta. O Portal √© um marco para aqueles que a contragosto deixaram suas terras como escravos para irem para as Am√©ricas. Me emocionei em v√°rios momentos!

title: Reminds of history's complicity and tragic moments
text: Specialists say that much of what you can see in present-day Ouidah as related to the history of slave trade does not follow history strictly. It may well be so. Yet, such monuments in any case remind us of how tragic history can be. The details can be unauthentic but the feelings such monuments rise are definitely related to historical truth, whatever it could be.

title: Ouidah - is on the future UNESCO site
text: Ouidah is very impressive. the history, the museum, the sites, the people, the restaurant, everything about Ouidah is magical.

title: Well worth a visit
text:
It is well worth walking the whole of the Route des esclaves. You can start from the Ouidah Museum of History and end at the gate of no return. The museum itself has some fascinating images showing the assimilation that took place from west African slaves bringing food, dance, and culture over to the Americas. The artifacts and images from the slave trade are horrific and it really makes you think about the dreadful conditions these people were forced into. Well worth the time to tour around. 

Entrance is free although, at the end of the tour, you donate what you want to the guide. Guides can be conducted in both French and English.

title: Une partie triste de l'histoire de l'humanit√©
text: M√™me si triste, il faut conna√Ætre et se souvenir de cet partie de l'histoire afin que jamais quelque chose de semblable ne se reproduise

title: Incontournable...
text: Si vous √™tes blanc √† faire avec l'humilit√© et le devoir de recueillement qui s'impose ici, le mus√©e comme tout autre lieux de m√©moire au B√©nin aurait besoin d'une bonne r√©habilitation, mais la visite reste incontournable et les diff√©rents guides restent tr√®s comp√©tant.

Il faut se documenter avant la visite et discuter du sujet apr√®s.
Int√©ressant pour les plus jeunes car cela permet d'initier une discussion sur les relations sociales en Afrique et le r√¥le des europ√©ens sur ce continent.

title: Un devoir de m√©moire.
text:
Une grande route qui am√®ne √† la plage ou √©taient embarqu√©s les esclaves.

title: Lieu tr√®s conseill√© remplis d'histoire
text: Bonjour , c'est un endroit tr√®s historique a visiter absolument. Si vous voulez faire partir de notre groupe de touristes internationaux pour visiter cet endroit et pleins d'autres au B√©nin a l'occasion de la f√™te annuelle du vodoun en Janvier 2020  , contactez moi: +447554783736 .

title: Sad history
text: Worth a visit for the important but sad slave history. Also very beautiful architecturally and poignant. There were local guides and definitely worth getting one.

title: Very sad history
text: It's quite an emotional journey following the route of the slaves. It is unbelievable what kind of cruelity they experienced. And to think that this was being done to them by fellow human being is pathetic. May this never happened again ever.

text: We walked the slave route starting from chacha place and ended at the gate of no return. A very powerful walk thinking about what the slaves that went through here went through. Would definitely recommend this.

title: Interesting history, great photos and pictures
text: It is the best establishment with regard to the history of slavery we have seen so far in the country  The Goulbenkian Foundation has done a great job in sending the collection and even though it is not well maintained, you find yourself looking eagerly at each and every exhibit. So interesting, so sad - not the least because of what the Africans did to their own people and how they exploited them so viciously

text: this places has a lot of history .a horrible period of mankind just because of skin colour. it was sad that a fellow human can treat other humans that way. we were escorted to slave markets, the final road before they were taken to slaves ship. we were told how the slaves were being treated before they took the slave ship to their master

title: rich history
text: The museum showcased the rich history and culture of the people of Benin and Ouidah. it also showed how most West African cultures are intricately linked.

text:

title: Interestinf

title: Interesting history
text: I was the only person visiting when I came and I found this trip interesting. They had an English speaking guide who led me around the large complex and explained everything. The buildings have lots of bas reliefs and there are some artefacts inside including many ancient thrones and decorative staffs and some gifts from Europeans during the slave trade. Not a huge amount of things but enough to keep interested and imaging how it would have been in its glory. The history was interesting. Took around an hour all in and the tour is mandatory, you can‚Äôt visit alone. Photos weren‚Äôt allowed inside the complex at all which was a pity, even the outside of building with the bas reliefs.

title: L'histoire des rois
text:
Le mus√©e ouvre √† 9H et sa visite est conditionn√©e par la pr√©sence d'un guide officiel sur place ; sauf qu'elle est arriv√©e √† pr√®s de 9H30.

Il y a certes quelques objets historique, mais rien de transcendant / exceptionnel / rare. 
La guide parlait doucement et me donnait envie de dormir ; cependant ce qui est racont√© sur l'√©poque des rois reste int√©ressant.

title: A Slice of Dahomean History
text:
Interesting site that focuses on the once great Dahomey empire. These are¬†the palaces of King Gh√©zo and King Gl√©l√© that has been turned into a museum.

The palaces showcase interesting bas reliefs, artifacts and collections. I had an English speaking guide who is very knowledgeable about the history and gave me a thorough explanation of the different sites within the palace. 

Only downside is you can‚Äôt take pictures inside the palace.

title: Fascinating place
text:
Located right in the heart of Abomey this is a great place to learn about the Benin Kingdom - a part of history completely neglected in my UK schooling. There are some very interesting artefacts and you can easily spend a couple of hours wandering around. Although some of the buildings are slightly falling into disrepair you do get the sense of what it must have been like at the height of the kingdom (surely the main aim of every museum right?) The English speaking guide was informative and very knowledgeable about this time period, which was good.

Only disappointing thing was we weren't allowed to take photos anywhere on the tour. Other than that, it's a highly educational morning out.

title: a place of history
text: a great place to learn abt History. the guide was totally great explain to us about the great Abomey Empire. he brought us room to room  and show us the abomey stuff ,the history of the kings,the warriors ,the wars ,how the abomey people lived during that time. after the guided tours, there were stalls of souvenir shops where u can buy stuff if you are interesed

title: Quick Visit
text: I was staying in Bohicon and went for to see the Royal Palace of Abomey, its not too far. I paid 500 CFA for a Zem to take me there. The entrance fee was 2500 CFA and that comes with a guided tour. Afterwards you can hire the guide again to take you around Abomey on a Moto if you'd like.

title: Full of history, the other edge of the brazilian slavery sistem
text: A great place to see that there was history outside europe. They never teach us this in the school in Brazil.

title: Visite
text: Dommage que nous ne puissions pas faire de photo, visite int√©ressante, un guide tr√®s comp√©tent connaissant sin sujet

text:
Visite incontournable du Palais des Rois d‚Äô Abomey . Pour s‚Äôimpr√©gner de la culture de cette r√©gion du B√©nin et comprendre son histoire .
Et puis √† la sortie l‚Äô artisanat propos√© est int√©ressant surtout pour les tissus.

title: Belle d√©couverte.
text: Visite √† faire avec un guide local, nous avions  "Mathieu" qui nous a fait d√©couvrir l histoire des rois avec beaucoup de passion. Nous n avons pas vu le temps pass√© 1h30. Ce fut une belle d√©couverte.

title: Un viaggio nel tempo....
text: Luogo interessante da visitare anche se non √® tenuto in buone condizioni. Merita comunque la visita se non altro per rendersi conto di come era strutturata la vita di corte in questa nazione africana. Nel cortile principale ci sono venditori di suvenir, c'√® anche un telaio per la tessitura con cui vengono prodette le stoffe che sono messe in vendita.

title: schreckliche pr√§sentation
text: Der k√∂nigliche Palast gibt wirklich nicht viel her , die wenigen Ausstellungsst√ºcke sind nicht beleuchtet, da st√§ndig der Strom gekappt wird . auf die Frage warum die F√ºhrerin keine Taschenlampe hat - nur Schulter zucken . alles verstaubt . Der letzte Raum mit K√∂nigsst√ºhlen und einigen Reliquien ist ok . Man muss ihn aber extra aufsperren .

title: Eher entt√§uschend
text: Ist die gleiche Sehensw√ºrdigkeit wie die Royal Palaces, also siehe die Bewertung dort. Zusammengefasst: trotz Weltkulturerbestatus kein wirkliches Highlight.

title: Eher entt√§uschend
text: Ein Weltkulturerbe, dass von au√üen noch halbwegs interessant aussieht, aber von innen leider nur wenig zu bieten hat. Einige der R√§ume zeigen Gegenst√§nde der alten K√∂nige und der F√ºhrer gibt sicher sein Bestes. Allerdings ist ein Fotografierverbot im Inneren der Pal√§ste und die Baustellenatmosph√§re eigentlich ein "No-Go" f√ºr ein Weltkulturerbe, zumal Fotos keine Sch√§den verursachen w√ºrden. OK, es ist eine Sehensw√ºrdigkeit, aber kein wirkliches Highlight.

title: Vietato fotografare.
text: Appena entrati, presso la biglietteria iniziano i cartelli che intimano di non fotografare n√© all'interno del palazzo n√© nei cortili interni ma soltanto nel cortile principale (dove ci sono i negozi di souvenir). Ci sono degli armadietti dove depositare le macchine fotografiche. Non si capisce bene la logica di tale divieto, che √® comunque sgradevole perch√© alcuni punti del palazzo sono molto fotogenici, in particolare le facciate con le nicchie con gli inserti scultorei e le porte di legno finemente intagliate. Il sito √® protetto dall'Unesco, ma la manutenzione lascia molto a desiderare. Le nicchie con le sculture sono piene di ragnatele e i prati incolti. Bruttissimi i tetti di lamiera, che hanno l'unico pregio di riprendere vagamente il color rosso terracotta dei palazzi e delle mura. Alcuni palazzi ospitano il museo, i cui pezzi salienti sono, a mio avviso, gli scettri reali (ce n'√® uno per ognuno dei re) e i troni. Il regno del Dahomey termina nell'anno 1900 con l'invasione francese.

title: A quick look around, getting jumped at
text: Visited the Artisanal Center to look at some souvenirs. A lot of small shops with handcrafted masks, jewellery, etc. A a caucasian you get more than enough attention, insect repellant does not work here ;-)

title: Handwerker- und K√ºnstlerdorf
text: Wie √ºberall in Afrika sind die H√§ndler f√ºr den europ√§ischen Geschmack eher aufdringlich - w√§ren wir auch, wenn wir von der Hand in den Mund leben w√ºrden. Benin ist kein touristisch erschlossenes Land. Es kommen wenig Touristen oder Rucksackreisende, die nicht viel Platz im Gep√§ck haben. Das Land ist bitter arm und es ist gut, diese organisierten Kunsthandwerker zu unterst√ºtzen.  Auf einem gro√üen Areal sind alle Arten von afrikanischen Handwerkern und K√ºnstlern vertreten. Fangen Sie allerdings ganz hinten im Dorf an. Die dortigen K√ºnstler bekommen selten Kunden, denn die Leute geben ihr Geld schon vorne aus. Ein gesch√ºtzter Bereich. Hier kann man gut parken. text:
L‚Äô enceinte des palais devrait √™tre assez impressionant, mais l‚Äô indifference pour la patrimoine de B√©nin par les autorit√©s de ce pays devraient drolement s‚Äô am√©liorer avant que la visite sois satisfaisant au lieu d‚Äô √™tre une grosse d√©ception.

Cependant, une petite d√©ception, j'aurais aim√© passer plus de temps sur les diff√©rents blasons et mieux observer l'architecture des palais. Il y a un art visuellement tr√®s riche qui s'√©tale sur les murs des palais et que l'on voit un peu d√©filer au pas de course... pour se concentrer sur les objets vaudous qui au final m'int√©resser peu.

text:
Une visite √† faire qui explique bien la dynastie du Dahomey qui s'√©tale sur 3 si√®cles avec ses 12 rois.
Il ne faut pas s'attendre √† trouver une architecture ph√©nom√©nale, ce sont des constructions en terre, mais il y a quelques expositions avec les si√®ges des rois, les autels portatifs, des manequins, photos, ... l'essentiel donc, qui se visite en 1h / 1h30.
Le guide (essentiel !) a su mettre en valeur et √† faire vivre le site.
Tarifs doux (2000 CFA pour de m√©moire pour les √©trangers), petit village artisanal.
B√©mol : photos interdites dans le site m√™me, toilettes pitoyables, pas d'eau pour laver mains, pas d'indication pour trouver le site (faut demander sur la route ;)

title: Un patrimoine √† prot√©ger
text: Le mus√©e est int√©ressant, on se laisse guider par un guide local qui connait bien l'histoire du pays et les petites anecdotes. Malheureusement, le mus√©e commence √† vieillir, les expositions sont peu prot√©g√©es et prennent l'humidit√©. Il reste peu de mus√©e de ce type au B√©nin, je trouve cela triste que leur patrimoine ne soit pas mieux pr√©serv√©.

title: Excellente visite
text: Tr√®s bel endroit, il vaut le d√©tour et les visites guid√©es sont de tr√®s bonnes qualit√©. Le personnel est agr√©able et fait partager sa passion pour l'histoire b√©ninoise.

title: Awesome souvenir shop
text: I went a week ago and it was odd that they randomly decided to close the palace visit 1hr early. I had the time to come the next day but it sucks for those with limited travel time. On the flip side, the market place is pretty awesome. I purchased a dinning table clothe with place setters despite lack of not having a dinning table, it was that beautiful.

title: interessante
text:
sicuramente un posto da visitare per capire come si viveva due secoli fa in africa. pur essendo un sito unesco la manutenzione lascia molto a desiderare, e se lo confrontiamo con i palazzi europei della stessa epoca riusciamo a comprendere perch√® l'africa √® terribilmente arretrata.
guida solo in francese

title: Explications tres claires de la part du guide
text: Cette visite du palais des rois d Abomey ( 12 rois jusque 1900) est tr√®s int√©ressante et les explications du guide sont tr√®s claires et permettent de vivre le passe

title: viaje a benin semana santa 2017
text: No es demasiado interesante si no te explican lo que ves y un poco la historia del reino de abomey y de sus reyes,todo es de barro y excepto en la plaza principal no se pueden sacar fotos.

title: decent visit
text:
The palaces are probably the highlight of Abomey but are not amazing.  Yes it is an interesting tour and your must do it if you are close but it wont blow you away at all.

Tour takes about an hour maybe a little more.  Interesting history for sure.  Can get hot and sunny so consider sunscreen for sure and bring water!!

title: You really need a guide to understand the stories behind the palaces
text: We had an excellent guide.  You can visit two of the 12 palaces (the only ones that survived when the then-king burned them down in 1892 as he fled the French invasion).  The buildings contain traditional thrones, weapons, etc.  On your way out, you can take a look at the handicrafts: some fairly good stuff actually made locally.

title: For history buffs!
text:
If you are interested in the history of Benin then this is a must-see UNESCO site. There are no pictures allowed inside and you can only visit two of the palaces as the rest are in ruins. Our English speaking guide was exemplary and by asking lots of questions we learnt a lot which brought together our knowledge from visiting other sites across Benin.

At the time of visiting we were made to pay an additional tourist tax of 1000 CFA which was advertised on the wall in French. We were given a receipt for this but it is worth bearing in mind for budgeting.

title: Great tour
text: The Palaces are very interesting as is the tour. If you do not speak French you may not understand all the information as the tour is very detailed.  Pictures are not allowed which is too bad, as it would be nice to revisit memories.

title: Abomey Palaces - A Royal Letdown
text:
The royal palaces of the Dahomey kingdom are spread all around the town of Abomey.

We are traveling around West Africa with a Togolese English-speaking guide. He suggested we begin our tour of the kings palaces with a visit to one palace that also houses the main museum. 

We didn't visit a second palace. 

Our visit to the palace was underwhelming. Yes it was interesting to see the architecture and a few of the items showcased in the museum, however the museum collection is spread all over the complex in small, dark rooms in locked buildings. 

A map of the complex is not available aside from a heavily weathered, to the point of being unreadable, plaque when you first enter. 

We were provided with a museum staff member who was supposed to be our guide, but he did essentially no guiding and just followed us around. I refuse to call him a guide. 

We wandered around the complex with our Togolese guide doing his best to recall what he'd learned on previous visits to the museum. 

We had to wait for our museum staff member to unlock every building before we could enter. 

You aren't allowed to take pictures for some reason and our unlocking staff member did double duty as our photo policeman. 

In my opinion, tourism works as follows: a tourist visits somewhere, takes photos, shares photos and the experience with others and inspires them visit as well....

Don't waste your time travelling all the way to Abomey to visit here.

title: Un mus√©e qui s'appauvrit
text:
Le mus√©e perd en qualit√© et s'appauvrit en objets d'ann√©e en ann√©e. Sans compter le fait que le prix vous sera demand√© avec un facteur 3 ou 4 par rapport aux locaux. 
Il reste tout de m√™me une part de l'histoire du B√©nin et m√©rite qu'on s'y attarde si on a un peu de temps

title: Interesting if you are into cultural history
text: Yes it is true, some of the palaces are not well preserved and not being taken care of. UNESCO efforts to restore and protect have been burned down several times "accidentally" by children igniting the grass around the structures to catch bushmeat. But a lot of archeological sites in the world have not a lot to see any more. The history behind those palaces is really fascinating and you can get a very good feel of the sites if you take some time and walk around the premises of the ruins. Locked front gates should not prevent you from it, everybody walks around them. The guide we hired from the tourist office was very helpful though not knowledgeable to an academical level naturally. We liked him anyhow and hired him next day to show us markets, places to eat and the museum. Official rate is CFA 4.000 for two hours plus 2.000 for the tourist office. Later one you can save if you hire him directly. We strongly recommend a guide, they are helpful, not expensive and you do a good job in directly supporting the young people there. Our official guide from the tourist center was the only English speaking one, we where his second customers this year in October.

title: Pas tr√®s bien mise en valeur mais des nouveaut√©s en perspectives
text:
Guides tr√®s bien parlant 3 langues : Fran√ßais, anglais, espagnol
Par contre le site n'est pas tr√®s bien mis en valeur et il faut pas h√©siter √† poser pleins de questions pour bien comprendre.
Le site est immense (45ha) mais tout ne se visite pas et surtout les photos sont interdites.
Ne pas h√©siter (si vous avez un v√©hicule) √† demander en fin de visite d'aller voir le foss√© p√©riph√©rique de protection pour bien comprendre comment √©tait organis√©e cette place forte.
Un pan d'histoire de toute la dynastie des rois de Dahomey, des guerres, du business de l'√©poque avec portugais puis fran√ßais ...

title: Une visite √† enrichir de lectures
text:
Si vous ne savez rien de l'histoire du royaume, vous aurez bien du mal √† comprendre. 
Abomey et son histoire se vivent au quotidien. Les guides ne sont pas toujours √† niveau, mais les efforts sont tout √† fait perceptibles pour rendre ce moment abordable au visiteur non initie et chaque b√©ninois  vous en contera... Un morceau... Avec sa vision... 
√Ä voir : les collections d'assens et tr√¥nes dans le mus√©e, les nombreuses cours et le village des artisans avec la boutique o√π vous trouverez de la documentation sur le site et des cartes postales. 
Compl√©tez la visite par un tour de ces 44 ha en Zem ou √† pied pour vous impr√©gner de ce haut lieu du patrimoine mondial : palais du roi Behanzin, palais d'Akaba,honnouwa d'Agadja, marche des amazones... 
Ce site est magique comme la ville, comme ce royaume encore tellement vivant, patrimoine de l'humanit√©.

title: Royal Palace and Museum
text: Well worth a visit. Unfortunately they wouldn‚Äôt let anyone take any pictures inside the palaces. The temple walls in the palaces are built from clay mixed with the blood of prisoners of war combined with gold dust, pearls and gunpowder. There is a royal throne inside which rests on the skulls of enemies.When a king died all of his wives were buried alive so that they could serve him in the after life. And most of the kings had more than 200 wives.Get a guide who can speak English, otherwise you cannot make head or tail of what you see.

title: rivivere la storia
text: √® stato veramente interessante entrare nel palazzo e immaginare come era nel passato: tante volte ci piacciono solo i grandi resti della nostra storia ( e niente da dire, sono certo eccezionali) ma anche conoscere altre "storie" ci pu√≤ permettere di imparare qualcosa che forse non avremmo immaginato

title: Very interesting museum
text: Old, not welltained,but very interesting museum. Each one should know about this horrible episode of mankind.

title: Beaucoup d'√©motion et une page noire de l'histoire de l'humanit√©
text: C'est certainement le lieu le plus marquant du B√©nin. Ici une grande part sombre de l'histoire de l'humanit√© s'est d√©roul√© avec le d√©but du circuits infernal de la traite des noirs en Afrique. Le mus√© est riche en repr√©sentation et les explications faite par le guide sont tr√®s claires. Aucuns point n'est oubli√© et la responsabilit√© de tous les acteurs est mis en √©vidence. La visite s'est faite avec un ado et un jeune enfant. C'est tr√®s important de connaitre cette partie de l'histoire. Autre point tr√®s int√©ressant, c'est la mise en √©vidence des similitudes culturelles et traditionnelles entre le Br√©sil et les pays d'Afrique de l'Ouest.

title: Know your history
text:
A lot of history!!! You must hear and see for yourself. The history of the trans Atlantic slave trade and African kingdoms that existed during the time is truly a revealing one.

It's amazing how black communities in the diaspora (in places such as South America and the Caribbean) have preserved certain elements of their culture for centuries and the striking similarities between those cultures and that of certain West African communities today. 

P.S. This museum needs a face lift however... without damaging the history; I felt that it wasn't in the best of shape.

title: Excursion Trip
text:
With about 45 persons that day we drove down to Ouidah from Cotonou, almost an hour.

The road is smooth and free.  Two years before now, we couldn't ply the slave route because it was flooded.  We had to turn back.

If you are going to the point of no return in Ouidah, get a tour guide who should be able to let you know if the route is in perfect state.

What makes this tour site a 'must go' is the story being told about the slave trade way back centuries from the route to the point of no return arc.

title: Emouvant
text: Visite ce site si vraiment tu  aimerais mieux connaitre l'histoire de l'esclavage. C'√©tait purement extraordinaire.

title: History cherished
text:
The museum is rich with antiques and it is encouraging to appreciate the managers for the preservations well done.

However, English speaking guides should be on a stand by for English speaking tourists.

It is a great place for those who value history.

title: Ouidah Museum
text: The museum have a lot of blood chilling history of slavey with lot of historical items  of how slavery was ran way back history.

title: Emotional Journey but Must Have a Guide
text:
My view may be a bit cloudy because it was an emotional place for me. This was a former slave Portuguese Fort that has been turned into a museum and you walk around rooms where pictures describe the unspeakable horrors slaves endured. We were on tour and the guide had arranged an English speaking guide for us who's a decent from a Brazilian slave who repatriated to Benin after slavery ended in Brazil. Of course, he admitted that his great grandfather at the time did not have knowledge of which country his ancestors had come from originally in Africa but he was following the wave of Brazilians who decided to call Ouidah home. 

I can't imagine visiting the museum without a guide because many of the pictures do not come with stories and that means you will miss out on so much. Plus the guide can help take you to the gate of no return which I think is part of the museum and also to other memorials which are there to honor slaves and the lives lost. It's a must do trip but just make sure to bring a guide!

title: No Museum, research the area and history before arriving
text: The Benin Government trying to help their citizens and visitors understand the history of the area and what has occurred here.  This is a monument not museum to the history of what took place here.  Research the trail and spend time to reflect this location and area before coming to the area.

title: The Museum of History of Ouidah has nothing to do with the Gate of No return Monument on the beach
text: The Gate of No return Monument on the beach,  of which there are a number of photographs here, is not The Museum of History of Ouidah. See the actual photo of the building which was originally Fort of S√£o Jo√£o Baptista de Ajud√° built by the Portugese. There is not a lot inside just a few rooms with some artefacts and some explanations in French. Most could be self explanatory without a guide but our guide was quite informative and did add to the experience.

title: Not Great Museum BUT
text: It achieves its effect of making one reflect on Man's inhumanity to Man. The Fort where the .museum is housed was the nub for the slave trade. The Benin authorities should seek international funding to make this Museum worthy of what it is about and to improve the exhibits and their housing. Worth a visit as part of an overall insight into the pernicious and evil slave trade

title: An idiots guide to the Atlantic slave trade.
text: The museum is housed in the old Portugeuse fort that doubled as a slave holding centre on the Benin coast of west Africa. It gives a "no holds barred" account of the way in which the slaves were taken, held, mistreated and eventually made to exit the fort to walk, in chains, down a mile long route to the coast where they would then board the slave ships for the middle passage across the Atlantic to the Americas. Being located in the original fort at Ouidah leaves the traveler with the sense of impending doom and helplessness that the stolen lives must have felt at the time.

title: Eye Opening
text: A eye opening walk through the atrocities that were inflected to the African race for greed. We had an amazing guide Fostine who gave us a thorough historical narrative on the impact of the slave trade and the significance of the monuments and historical pieces. It is a place to visit and I was very happy that a lot of the historical monuments and artifacts were kept in good shape because in a lot of these historical sites things are not archived correctly. It is a beautiful village and you will get your fill with souvenir traders at the actual entrance to the beach Door Of No Return.

title: History of Benin
text:
Interesting history of Benin, a lot about slave trade.
Interesting museum and then follow the slave route to the monument. 
Ouidah is worth visiting for everyone who wants to get to know beninoise culture and history. Make sure you hire a local guide!

title: sensational
text: This is a sensationnel place, this is a part of history because slaves were deported thru this door.

title: Beautiful setting
text: This is the place where the people left when sold into slavery. It is hard to describe the feelings I had as I stood there at the beautiful monument honoring those who were forced to leave their homeland. It is one of those places that changes your perspective forever.

title: Impresionante recorrido
text: Lugar delque partian los esclavos, y tiene muchas cosas relacionadas con el tema que son muy interesantes, y merece la pena verlo, la fortaleza Portuguesa, LA PUERTA DEL NO RETORNO, CON SUS CUATRO KILOMETROS  DERECORRIDO.

title: Excellent et rem√©morant
text: Tr√®s bonne exp√©rience avec la rencontre d'une population accueillante, souriante. On a la possibilit√© de revenir avec de bons souvenirs comme des tableaux peints, des perles, des statuettes fabriqu√©es en bois

title: un monument aux esclaves
text: C'est un endroit de m√©moire qui est mal entretenu et qui est un pi√®ge √† touristes. Les √©critures s'effacent et deviennent illisibles.

title: Important Piece of History
text: Symbolic of a dark time in human history, the exhibits are basic and only a few are from the era.  If you are in Ouidah it is a must see.

title: Sans majeur interet.
text: Ce matin, quelques enfants jouent sur la plage... un campement de militaire, sinon rien de sp√©cial. Cet endroit n'est pas tr√®s propre ni accueillante. Nous nous ne sommes pas attard√©s sur cet plage.

title: Beach Named After OBAMA in Cotonou, Benin, Africa!
text:
I tried to find ‚ÄúObama Beach‚Äù yesterday but overshot it and ended up at ‚ÄúFamily Beach‚Äù. Today I finally located Obama Beach. A beach named after Obama just has to be awesome- and it is!

I really enjoyed seeing huge poster of Barack Obama everywhere. My favorite President of the USA!!!!

There was a playground for kids and horsey rides on the beach!

There were tons of people! Nobody was swimming though. The waves are too rough.  However, I stayed there and watched the sun go down to the West. 

Enjoy my photos of OBAMA BEACH!

title: Worth coming to.
text: Beautiful ambiance , safe, conducive and very clean.  All hands were on deck as per sweeping & cleaning when we got there on a Sunday morning for our photoshoot

title: Sch√∂ne Beach
text: Die Beach liegt direkt an einer Hauptverkehrsstrasse. Es wird vor Kleinkriminellen gewarnt. Um die Beach zu geniesen am besten aufpassen oder in einer Gruppe hingehen

title: Wide stretches of sand and very few people
text:
The beach is quite wide, with very good sand. The ocean view is beautiful. But locals warned me that the beach is considered quite dangerous for swimming, due to the strong currents. 

In some areas of Cotonou, they seem to be trying to plant lots of palm trees on the beaches. This may change the appearance in the future.

title: Good and safe environment to relax
text:
Such a beautifull beach in west Africa I really enjoyed my visit and  recommend it to anyone else to visit.
You will love it ,Benin Royal Hotel will provide you free information and transportation if you stay there it's a perfect hotel to stay in Benin.

title: Ok
text: Just be careful on all African beaches. Often out of view and can be seen as fair targets. Not saying ‚Äúdon‚Äôt go‚Äù but just be wise. I love Benin so I am not running it‚Äôs beaches down. But we are not in the West.

text: ÿ¥ÿßÿ∑ÿ¶ ŸáÿßÿØÿ¶ Ÿàÿ¨ŸÖŸäŸÑ ÿå Ÿäÿπÿ™ÿ®ÿ± ŸÖŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿßŸÖÿßŸÉŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸÑŸäŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ŸäŸÖŸÉŸÜ ÿ≤Ÿäÿßÿ±ÿ™Ÿáÿß ŸàÿßŸÑÿßÿ≥ÿ™ŸÖÿ™ÿßÿπ ÿ®ÿßŸÑÿßÿ¨Ÿàÿßÿ° ÿßŸÑŸáÿßÿØÿ¶ÿ© ÿ®ŸÖÿØŸäŸÜÿ© ŸÉŸàÿ™ŸàŸÜŸà

title: C'est vraiment un super endroit o√π il faut s√©journer !
text: La plage est super, il y a un restaurant proposant une bonne cuisine √† un prix raisonnable, d'une plage qui est vraiment superbe et il y avait plein de choses √† faire.

title: Plus aucune installation
text: Cette plage √©tait tr√®s populaire pour y passer un apr√©s midi nous avions t'on dit. Nous avons √©t√© tr√®s d√©√ßu. Toutes les installations de paillotes en bord de plage ont √©t√© ras√© par d√©cision du gouvernement pour mettre en conformit√© la r√©glementation. Mais rien n'a √©t√© mis en place pour remplacer. Du coup, on a une belle plage, immense, mais rien √† faire. Les familles viennent quand m√™me le WE pour pic-niquer.

title: Go next door to "Family beach" instead
text:
Only one meal out of more than 6 options was available - chicken & chips (fries). In fairness, the chicken was good. Then drinks, more than half the options were not available either.
A loud generator is used to light the location at night
You have to pay a 200 CFA entrance fee
The seats are wooden chairs, no cushion and very uncomfortable
The staff took 20 minutes to calculate a bill of 8,000 CFA and the drinks vendor is different from the food vendor, so they want to be paid seperately
The food vendor doesn't arrive on time, so consider having a meal before heading there, if you are really hungry
There are dogs on the premises (at least 3), in case you don't like them
Nice space but so much more can be done to make it better

title: Great Beach but don't go in the water - you will get swept away!
text:
My colleagues and I wandered down to Obama Beach a few times - the bar / resto there is very cheap and food is good (so is the beer!!!)
However the sea is so dangerous that you really shouldn't go anywhere near it 
An evening in bar there would be great -thnk I'll do that next time!

title: Yellow summer oblige
text: En Sep 2017 j ai assiste au concert de Yellow summer et il avait un monde fou et ce fut une experience particuliere.

title: After 4
text: We arrived about 12 and the bar/ club was empty.  Apparently people arrive about 4 pm. Looked like it might be fun.  Beach supporting clean

title: "Neat waves"
text: This beach is located opposite the US embassy and I guess that's why it's called the "Obama" beach". It's a fun place to spend the day with the children. I suggest that you visit the beach early and leave before it gets crowded.

title: Clean beach
text: It wasn't spectacular in my opinion, but it was clean in comparison to most of the beaches I've been. My date had more fun taking pictures, it was just okay to me.

title: poor
text: the day i went, very few people around so visit wasn't that eventful. not much to eat...no choices to make just between 2 dishes

title: Fantastic place to spend an afternoon at the beach
text:
This is such a great place to go to!
The beach is great, there is a a restaurant with good food at really reasonable prices, a beach that is quite beautiful and plenty of things to do!
You can sun tan, swim, play football with any of the locals having a beach soccer game, play volley ball or simply take a long walk on the beach!
A worthy place if you just want to have a good time, with simple activities requiring little money

title: Not worth the visit
text: I am born in cotonou but lived a broad for more than 20 years. I decide to visit on my 25th birthday. The town is terrible to drive in with all the taxi moto. That beach? No point going there. I dont see the point. There are plenty of nice hidden beach in the country.  drive along the coast on the road to lome in Togo. Afer or around the town of Grand Popo stop in any of the village and enjoy the quietness of some clean beach. You can even get the local fisherman to provide you with fresh fish. It take a little talk to get it fried by any woman in the village to perfection. How much will it cost you? NothibNothing. Benin people are the lovliest in west Africa

title: Cotonou Beaches
text: Cotonou is the business capital of Benin.For relaxation point of view you can visit beaches mainly on weekends, there are few good beached near Fidjrosse area.You can find few small restaurant for drinks and snacks.You can eoither hire taxi or bike to go there.The max amount for bike charge will be around 400-500 CFA and it may come down depend on how good you bargain.

title: Plage agr√©able
text: La plage est agr√©able mais pas toujours tr√®s propre, c'est un endroit assez fr√©quent√© qui n'offre pas la tranquillit√© d'autres moins connues √† Cotonou

title: De toute beaut√©
text:
Plage √† perte de vue, beaucoup de p√™cheurs...
Il y a des paiottes √† louer et les petits maquis sur le bord de l'oc√©an servent des gambas..excellent et surtout tr√®s frais...

title: Au pied de l'Oc√©an Atlantique
text:
Fidjross√® Beach est une belle plage de Cotonou au B√©nin, tr√®s bien fr√©quent√©e et tr√®s anim√©e les week-end. Il faut y aller tr√®s t√¥t √† partir de 11h ou 12h, pour √™tre parmi les premiers afin de trouver de bonne place pour s'installer. Il faut √©galement quitter assez t√¥t aux environs de 18h afin d'√©viter les embouteillages de sortie de plage qui peuvent vous faire perdre parfois plusieurs heures. Je conseille aux int√©ress√©s qui supportent moins les rayons de soleil, de louer les paillotes disponibles tout au long de la plage. Elles sont √† co√ªt abordable.
La mer est agit√©e et nerveuse; il faut √™tre tr√®s exp√©riment√© pour s'y baigner.
Il existe √† cet endroit une convivialit√© exceptionnelle.

title: Belle plage √† voir m√™me si pas trop propre
text:
La plage est belle m√™me si pas trop propre : un quartier un peu mis√©reux la borde, √† voir cependant. Les vagues sont fortes et la baignade d√©conseill√©e.
BernardO

title: pas du tout mal
text: le monde les manifestations et beaucoup d'autre choses. il a un r√©seau du pays qui organise chaque dimanche une manifestation. il ram√®ne souvent des artistes qui vienne anim√©. A cot√© aussi il y a village de vacance, ou on rencontre beaucoup de jeunes .

title: la playa bonita
text: la beaut√© de la mer et sa fraicheur me donnent le plaisir de toujours venir √† leur rencontre, il y avait des beaux arbres de tailles longues avec de fueilles vertes

title: Always Go!!
text: Benin has loely beaches. This especailly is clean unlike other west african states. No one really disturbs you except that francophone west africans are polite and would hardly walk past without a brief ''bonjour''. Calm and good to walk on in the mornings.

title: Security and sand.
text: Security is not good and the sand is dirty, also to get there, depends on where you are, you have to "prevent" studying better the way to do it.

title: Don't go after dark!
text: benin is an ok country but its beaches are an hazard. not only if would be very unsafe to go there after dark but the simple act of swimming is strongly non advisable. the undertows are so strong that i have seen even very good swimmers in serious distress. avoid if you have kids at all costs. on the other hand all along the beach runs a beautiful coconut lined road that will make your SUV work. again, never stop along the way. just drive from cotonou the 'la port de non retour' and stop.

title: Sandstrand und Fischer
text:
Fidjross√© lohnt einen Aufenthalt von einigen Tagen. Der Strand ist weitl√§ufig und ziemlich menschenleer. Palmen s√§umen den Strand, morgens sieht man die Fischer aus den D√∂rfern ihre Netze einholen.
Von Cotonou aus ist Fidjross√© in 30 bis 45 Minuten zu erreichen, je nach Abfahrtsort.
Tourismus ist hier nur begrenzt vorhanden. Das bringt den Vorteil mit sich, dass man den Strand f√ºr sich hat, allerdings fehlt es auch an einer touristischen Infrastruktur. Zwar gibt es √úbernachtungsm√∂glichkeiten, aber √∂ffentlicher Transport ist nicht vorhanden. Fr√ºh morgens f√§hrt wohl ein Buschtaxi nach Ouidah. Wenn man mitgenommen werden m√∂chte, sollte man dem Fahrer am Vortag Bescheid geben. Ansonsten ist man auf Taxis angewiesen (die man allerdings auch bestellen muss). Gr√∂√üter Nachteil ist die Verschmutzung. Am Strand wir viel Plastikm√ºll angeschwemmt, auch im Wasser schwimmt allerlei herum. Die Str√∂mung ist sehr stark, man sollte also keinesfalls zu weit herausschwimmen - auch wenn die tosenden Wellen weiter drau√üen verlockend aussehen.

title: un endroit tr√®s agr√©able
text:
La plage de Fidjross√® est l'une des meilleures plages de Cotonou. On est beaucoup plus √† l'aise lorsqu'on va dans les bungalow qui sont vers la route de Ouidah. 
Par contre la mer est un peu dangereuse et on ne peut pas toujours y nager.
Mon exp√©rience globale l√†-bas a √©t√© vraiment tr√®s agr√©able! je le conseille √† tous ceux qui vont au B√©nin.

title: Pas mal mais ne vaut que moyennement le d√©placement de Cotonou
text: Comme la plupart des autres sites que j‚Äôai voulu visiter au B√©nin, ce palais-musee √©tait en r√©novation. On pouvait n√©anmoins en visiter une partie, ce qui a √©t√© int√©ressant au moins autant par la le√ßon d‚Äôhistoire de l‚Äôexcellent guide que pour le palais lui-m√™me et les quelques vestiges qui y restaient, tous deux assez d√©cevants.

title: Mus√©e Honm√© et Palais du roi Te Agbanlin √† Hogbonou ( Porto Novo ), Patrimoine en p√©ril !!
text:
Ce mus√©e dit Honm√© , √©tabli dans l'ancien palais du roi Te Agbanlin (1710-1760) , de Hogbonou , aujourd'hui Porto Novo ( Sud Est du B√©nin) , date de 1725 . A cette √©poque , le puissant  royaume d'Abomey envahit celui d 'Allada ( centre Sud du B√©nin actuel ). Ce qui conduit son roi √† se r√©fugier √† Hogbonou o√π depuis 1600 le fr√®re du Premier roi d'Abomey Gangnihessou (1600-1620) , y a r√©gn√©. Autant dire qu'il s'agit d'une histoire de famille ,mais qu'importe. 

Le roi Te Agbanlin , √† son arriv√©e, trouve une situation difficile o√π les musulmans Yoruba venus du Nig√©ria voisin (Royaume d'Oyo ) , occupent la cit√© . Ici nous rentrons dans la l√©gende avec l'intervention du Dieu vaudou de la nuit, Zangbeto , qui √©loigne les mauvais esprits et du coup les occupants Yoruba sont chass√©s .( SIC)

La dynastie, qui s'y √©tablie, r√®gnera jusqu'en 1882 quand,  pour se prot√©ger de ses ennemis du royaume du Dahomey associ√© √† celui de Ouidah ( Sud Ouest du B√©nin actuel)  , le roi Toffa de Porto Novo (1874-1908) , se met sous la protection de la France . Un accord de protectorat est conclu avec Paris .
Face √† cette situation de menace de la part du royaume du Dahomey , la France prend pr√©texte et engage les hostilit√©s contre le roi B√©hanzin d'Abomey . En 1894 la France , qui a vaincu toute opposition , √©tablit la colonie du Dahomey . Le port de Porto Novo est florissant ainsi que la cit√© . Le royaume  ne sera int√©gr√©e √† la colonie du Dahomey qu'√† la mort du roi Toffa en 1908 .  

La visite est d√©cevante , du fait de la v√©tust√© des lieux et ce malgr√© les explications du guide. Le palais est construit en terre rouge de la r√©gion qui , au fil du temps , lui donne une patine grise , faute de restauration  . Il n'y a aucun meuble les pi√®ces sont vides .L' interdiction de prendre des photos , est de mon point de vue contre productive pour la promotion du site . Ceci √©tant dit , vue l'√©tat des lieux , ce n'est peut √™tre pas souhaitable pour l'instant . Le gouvernement b√©ninois , conscient de la valeur symbolique et touristique du patrimoine , "devrait" engager un programme de r√©novation . Je pr√©cise aussi que certaines photos qui apparaissent ne correspondent absolument pas √† ce lieu , notamment la photo de couverture . Cela a √©t√© signal√© , mais rien ne bouge !!

Nous entrons dans chaque pi√®ce par une porte basse , qui oblige √† se courber et nous sortons par la grande porte , initialement r√©serv√©e au seul Roi . 
Les pi√®ces se succ√®dent , avec des fonctions tr√®s pr√©cises comme , le vestibule , la salle de r√©ception , la salle de la Reine M√®re , etc Puis on acc√®de √† la salle du Conseil du Roi , Etrangement , une cour √† toit ouvert entour√©e de coursives , poss√®de une cabane tr√®s sommaire en branche en son milieu . C'√©tait para√Æt il le lieu o√π le jeune roi commen√ßait son apprentissage et o√π ,  ensuite il pouvait se retirer pour m√©diter .
L'espace r√©serv√© aux multiples √©pouses du roi , sous la surveillance de la Reine m√®re. , est √† toit ouvert , avec un bassin central vide au milieu d'une coursive . 
Enfin, nous terminons la visite du palais par un grand espace en herbe rase entour√© de gradins couverts pour le roi et les dignitaires  et de banquettes pour les spectateurs . Cet espace √©tait r√©serv√© pour les manifestations royales .
A l'ext√©rieur ,on peut voir l'arbre de justice puis le tribunal ,avec les attributs traditionnels . 

Des ≈ìuvres d'Art inspir√©es du Vaudou , sont expos√©es devant l'entr√©e , comme le Dieu de la foudre,  un serviteur royal au crane ras√© , un laboureur , un √©trange personnage style robot Antique ou encore un facteur √† v√©lo , m√©tallique et rouill√© . C'est de l'art certes , mais un peu d√©sordonn√© !!
Le terme " Honm√© " d√©signe " ce qui est √† l'int√©rieur de la porte " par extension " le Palais "

title: A very moving monument.
text: The beauty of this location stands in stark contrast to the terrible history it memorializes.  This beachside monument marks the place where untold numbers of African slaves departed from their homeland. The images on the monuments largely speak for themselves, however I would still strongly recommend obtaining a local guide to provide further explanation of the historical and cultural significance of this place. Overall, I highly recommend visitors to this area of Africa to take a trip to see this and the other elements in this town which memorialize the slave trade.

title: Diesen 6 km langen Weg sollte man auf jeden Fall sich ansehen
text: Es ist der alte Weg, der vom Sklavenmarkt in Ouidah bis zum Strand verl√§ft( zum Verladen der insgesamt 11,8 Mio Sklaven, die damals vorwiegend von hier nach S√ºdamerika verschifft wurden. Die Skulpturen am Rande sind brasilianischen Ursprungs. Gerade nach Benin sind dim 18. und 19. Jahrhundert viele Nachkommen der damaligen Sklaven in ihre alte Heimat zur√ºck gegehrt, nach dem Sie in der neuen Welt zu Reichtum gekommen sind. Sie begr√ºndeten sie besidnere afro-brasilianische Archtitektur, wovon noch vielin OUidah zu sehen ist. Diewer " Sklavenweg " geh√∂rt einfach dazu!

title: a voir...
text:
Bien entendu, cette construction ne date pas de l'√©poque de l'esclavage et est un monument comm√©moratif.

On ne peut pas, √† mon avis arriver comme √ßa, presque par hasard devant ce symbole aussi terriblement charg√© d'histoire. 
On doit s‚Äôimpr√©gner tout d'abord du drame qu'ont v√©cus plus d'un million d'esclaves en ces lieux, certains pr√©f√©rant mourir sur place plut√¥t que de partir...
Pour cela, il est n√©cessaire de faire le chemin en commen√ßant par le commencement, √† savoir la visite de l' ancien fort portugais, actuel mus√©e de Ouidah, et de suivre le chemin de 4 km qu'empruntaient les esclaves jusqu'√† cette plage.
